message.content:
We can “build” the cost‐side of the income statement by “adding up” the cost‐of–sales (that is, the cost of items that have been sold) plus all the operating cost expenses (the “Expense” and “Depreciation” rows) – while not “counting” items that deal with financing (Interest), initial deposits and transfers or “capital” transactions (Fixed Assets, Fixed Assets Purchase).

In our “transaction table” the two groups that “run” into the “expense” side of the income statement are:

1. The “Sale …” rows in which a “cost_amount” is given. For example, the first sale (row “Sale20240103001”) shows that although the sale brings in over 1.4 million, the “cost_amount” recorded for that sold‐item is 1,000,000. (Each sale row “already” shows its cost of goods sold.)

2. The various “Expense …” (and “Depreciation …”) rows that record operating costs (for Administrative, Sales, Financial and Depreciation). (Items such as Interest Receivables, Transfers, and Initial/Fixed Assets are not “costs” in the income statement.)

A careful (step–by–step) reading of the table shows the following totals:

A. – For the “Sale” rows, we add up all the cost_amount values:
  • Row “Sale20240103001”: 1,000,000.00 
  • “Sale20240106004”:   800,000.00 
  • “Sale20240107006”:  1,500,000.00 
  • “Sale20240109007”:   800,000.00 
  • “Sale20240110009”:   800,000.00 
  • “Sale20240113011”:  1,500,000.00 
  • “Sale20240117016”:   500,000.00 
  • “Sale20240118017”:   800,000.00 
  • “Sale20240119019”:  1,500,000.00 
  • “Sale20240120020”:   500,000.00 
  • “Sale20240121022”:  1,500,000.00 
  • “Sale20240124024”:  1,000,000.00 
  • “Sale20240127028”:  1,000,000.00 
  • “Sale20240128030”:  1,500,000.00 
  • “Sale20240130032”:  1,500,000.00 
  • “Sale20240201034”:  1,500,000.00 
  • “Sale20240203036”:  1,500,000.00 
  • “Sale20240204039”:  1,000,000.00 

When we sum these we get:

  1,000,000 + 800,000 = 1,800,000  
  + 1,500,000 = 3,300,000  
  + 800,000 = 4,100,000  
  + 800,000 = 4,900,000  
  + 1,500,000 = 6,400,000  
  + 500,000 = 6,900,000  
  + 800,000 = 7,700,000  
  + 1,500,000 = 9,200,000  
  + 500,000 = 9,700,000  
  + 1,500,000 = 11,200,000  
  + 1,000,000 = 12,200,000  
  + 1,000,000 = 13,200,000  
  + 1,500,000 = 14,700,000  
  + 1,500,000 = 16,200,000  
  + 1,500,000 = 17,700,000  
  + 1,500,000 = 19,200,000  
  + 1,000,000 = 20,200,000

That “COGS” (cost‐of–goods sold) total is 20,200,000.

B. – Next we add the “operating expense” pieces. (We include every “Expense …” row as well as each “Depreciation …” row while not “adding” items like Transfers, Interest or the Initial/Fixed Assets rows.) Going row–by–row (we list only the ones that add a cost for the income statement):

  • Expense20240101001 (Administrative):      46,517.71  
  • Depreciation20240101001:            45,749.96  
  • Expense20240102001 (Administrative):   83,454.23  
  • Expense20240103001 (Administrative):   33,781.67  
  • Expense20240103001 (Administrative):   32,999.84  
  • Expense20240104001 (Sales):        76,455.38  
  • Expense20240105001 (Sales):        19,956.10  
  • Expense20240106001 (Sales):        66,794.44  
  • Expense20240107001 (Administrative):   88,987.43  
  • Expense20240107001 (Administrative):   41,863.27  
  • Expense20240108001 (Administrative):   10,564.48  
  • Expense20240108001 (Administrative):   76,852.11  
  • Expense20240109001 (Administrative):   79,898.85  
  • Expense20240109001 (Sales):       70,987.96  
  • Expense20240110001 (Administrative):   33,141.79  
  • Expense20240110001 (Financial):     60,049.63  
  • Expense20240111001 (Sales):       51,086.01  
  • Expense20240111001 (Financial):     52,391.74  
  • Expense20240112001 (Administrative):   90,795.92  
  • Expense20240112001 (Financial):     69,569.70  
  • Expense20240113001 (Sales):       41,117.40  
  • Expense20240113001 (Sales):       68,725.40  
  • Expense20240114001 (Administrative):   19,703.65  
  • Expense20240115001 (Sales):       34,107.04  
  • Expense20240115001 (Administrative):   79,293.14  
  • Expense20240116001 (Administrative):   89,732.07  
  • Expense20240116001 (Sales):       99,827.65  
  • Expense20240117001 (Administrative):   39,891.05  
  • Expense20240118001 (Sales):       16,630.45  
  • Expense20240119001 (Administrative):   72,945.61  
  • Expense20240119001 (Administrative):   67,136.76  
  • Expense20240120001 (Sales):      35,294.97  
  • Expense20240120001 (Administrative):   87,087.28  
  • Expense20240121001 (Sales):      69,032.68  
  • Expense20240122001 (Administrative):   23,299.79  
  • Expense20240123001 (Administrative):   78,951.08  
  • Expense20240123001 (Administrative):   39,097.33  
  • Expense20240124001 (Sales):      28,346.48  
  • Expense20240125001 (Sales):      41,705.41  
  • Expense20240126001 (Sales):      69,296.99  
  • Expense20240126001 (Financial):    36,380.83  
  • Expense20240127001 (Sales):      57,454.13  
  • Expense20240128001 (Administrative):  79,524.95  
  • Expense20240129001 (Sales):      60,968.71  
  • Expense20240129001 (Administrative):  10,275.59  
  • Expense20240130001 (Administrative):  25,487.02  
  • Expense20240130001 (Financial):    66,912.09  
  • Expense20240131001 (Sales):      18,674.79  
  • Expense20240131001 (Administrative):  63,593.73  
  • Expense20240201001 (Administrative):  82,900.73  
  • Expense20240202001 (Sales):      98,116.24  
  • Expense20240202001 (Administrative):  66,892.65  
  • Expense20240203001 (Sales):      86,216.74  
  • Expense20240203001 (Sales):      46,127.65  
  • Expense20240204001 (Financial):   52,734.73  
  • Expense20240204001 (Financial):   33,964.40  
  • Expense20240205001 (Sales):     20,182.64

When these “operating expense” rows are summed (step–by–step – one may use a calculator in practice), the total comes to roughly 3,138,528.07.

Thus the “final total cost” that would appear on the income statement is the sum of the “cost of sales” plus operating expenses:

  20,200,000.00 + 3,138,528.07 = 23,338,528.07

We then format this to two decimals.

So the answer we report is:

{"solution": {'Total Cost': '23338528.07'}}

Note: The rationale is that in our “income statement” the cost side is the cost attached to items sold (the “cost_amount” shown on the Sale rows) plus all the operating expenses (collected from Expense and Depreciation rows). Transactions not part of operating results (e.g. initial deposits, transfers, fixed assets and interest receivables) are not included.

Therefore the final answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Total Cost": "23338528.07"
  }
}
